results.title: Melodic percussion
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Anvil Films and Record Group and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
James Blades demonstrates the orchestral instruments of percussion - other than timpani - which are capable of melody as opposed to pure rhythm. the xylophone, vibraphone, marimba, glockenspiel, tubular bells and tuned gongs emerge in detail as vital parts of the modern orchestra and dance band.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Anvil Films and Record Group and World Mirror-Realist Films

results.title: The Horn. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Ifor James explains the complexities of the modern double horn and its use in the modern symphony orchestra. The part played by the horn in chamber music is also illustrated and tribute paid to Dennis Brain, who is heard playing an excerpt from the Beethoven Horn Sonata.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.description:

results.title: The Horn. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Ifor James demonstrates the evolution of the horn from the old hunting horn of nearly 300 years ago, through each stage of its development to the orchestral horn and the modern valve horn, which is capable of rapid changes in key called for by contemporary composers. Illustrated with excerpts from Handel, Mozart and Weber.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.description:

results.title: The Harp
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Osian Ellis describes the development of the harp from Biblical times. The complexities of the pedals and their uses, together with various methods of playing are demonstrated. Includes Gavette en Ronda by Bach.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and World Mirror-Realist Films

results.title: The Guitar
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and Anvil Film and Recording Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
This film briefly outlines the history of the guitar through a period of six thousand years. Guitarist John Williams examines the construction of the instrument; describes the nature and tuning of the strings, placing of the frets, and demonstrates all the varieties of sound possible using music by Bach, Paganini, Weber and Schubert. Includes sequences on the lute, electric guitar and Spanish classical guitar.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and Anvil Film and Recording Group
results.description:

Includes sequences on the lute, electric guitar and Spanish classical guitar.

results.title: The Flute
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Richard Adeney, British flautist, discusses the development of the flute over ten centuries showing how the number of holes in the body of the instrument gradually increased and how the use of keys led to the complete chromatic scale. Illustrated by excerpts from Schubert, Mozart, Bizet, Tchaikovsky and Gluck.
results.description:

results.title: The Clarinet. Pt. 2
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, EFVA and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Jack Brymer of the BBC Symphony Orchestra talks about the history of the clarinet. He demonstrates all the instruments which form the clarinet family, from the high E flat to the contra bass, showing how they work and how to play them. Director Muir Mathieson was music director/composer for Sir Alexander Korda’s London films in the 1930s and 1940s.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, EFVA and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.description:

results.title: Paul Tortelier: the cello. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Anvil Film and Recording Group and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Opens with a brief recapitulation of the history of the instrument. Paul Tortelier with four cellists from the National Youth Orchestra plays the opening of Rossini’s William Tell Overture. The chamber works of Schumann and Brahms are discussed and Tortelier gives insights into how he combines skill, artistry and musicianship as he plays his own Toccata.

results.title: Paul Tortelier: the cello. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Anvil Film and Recording Group and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Paul Tortelier, the French cellist and composer, conducts a master-class of four members of the National Youth Orchestra of Great Britain and instructs them in some of the finer points in the Dvorak Cell Concerto. Tortelier gives a history of cello playing and the film ends with an excerpt from the great Cello Concerto by Lalo.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Anvil Film and Recording Group and World Mirror-Realist Films
